abstract: Is political gridlock really good for the stock market? Researchers found that more than 90 percent of the price gains over the 108-year life of the Dow Jones industrial average through 2006 came on days when Congress was out of session.
snippet: Is political gridlock really good for the stock market? Researchers found that more than 90 percent of the price gains over the 108-year life of the Dow Jones industrial average through 2006 came on days when Congress was out of session.
lead_paragraph: From Jeff Sommer writing in The New York Times’s Strategies column:

headline.main: If Congress Stalls, Do Stocks Rise?
